div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

TUESDAY, JANUARY 22, 1907

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: Wo beg to tender our hearty congratulations to the Khedive of Egypt on the anniversary of his accession. On an occasion like the present it is both customary and opportune to pass in review the chief events of the sovereign's reign. Rut such a survey would be inadequate without endeavouring to estimate the bearing of such events upon the present situation and their probable influence on the future. The most important of these events from this point of view, as standing out prominently from among the rest, and as calculated to make his Highness's reign famous oven in the lengthy roll of Egypt's history, are t^o extension of her dominions by the restoration of her lost provinces in the .Sudan and the building of the Assouan Dam. The former has assured to this country durable peace upon her borders and has manifested to the world at large the bravery and capacity of her soldiers when pitted against a most valiant foe. But that brilliant feat of arms has been rivalled, if not surpassed, by the greatest of engineering triumphs which the modern world has wit- nesaéd, and whicli must necessarily be chief amongst the factors contributing to her future prosperity. These events, even if unaccompanied by many useful ameliorations in almost every department of the Administration, would l>e sufficient to lend lustre and distinction to his Highness's reign. At a moment like tho present, one naturally asks oneself what are the main features of tho era inaugurated by the accession of the Khedive, and tho conclusion suggested is that coming ages will note this epoch as a period of peaceful progress and prolonged prosperity.

Called suddenly to the Throne at the age of eighteen, the Khedive was brought faco to face with a most difficult situation. But despite his youth and consequent inexpcrienco and tho absence of far-seeing advisers, his-Highness lias risen superior to all the intrigues to which many a ruler of maturer years, though less richly endowed with the qualities of firmness, courage, and discrimination, might very well have succumbed. It is manifest to those who have closely watched his Highness's career that the dangers by which fce was formerly surrounded are now entirely removed, and recent years have shown that the future which awaits him has all the elements of permanent well-being ami advancement.

If we have accurately gauged the situation and rightly cast the horoscope of coming events, there lies before his Highness Abbas II. a future of such promise as may well be envied ^by many an ambitious potentate on the European continent, a future, indeed, which should amply satisfy the aspirations of one so practical in his aims and so reasonable in his desires.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY.
TO-DAY'S CELEBRATIONS.
div.p: To-day, on the oocasion of the anniversary of the accession ot H.H. the Khedive,Cairo bean a festive appearanoe. Everywhere are signs of rejoicing and loyalty to the throne. The principal streets of the Capital are gaily deoorated with banting, and the hotels, snob as Shep beard's and 1 h9 Grand Continental, have no Bmall share in the scheme of decoration, the most remarkable feature of which is a large triomphal arch which has been ereoted near the railway atation, at the entrance to the city

The reception held by H.H. the Khedive at Abdeen Palaoe this morning was more than nsnally well attended, and the stream of carriages conveying the Khedive's distinguished visitors was a source of great interest to the tourists who happened to be on the route to the Palace, at ihe entrance to which a gnard of hononr was drawn up to pay the nsnal oompli- ments to the members of the Diplomatic Corps.
At noon a sainte of 21 gnns was fired from the Citadel and the Polygon barracks, similar saintes being fired at Alexandria and Port Said.

This afternoon at 3.10 p.m. his Highness will review the Egyptian troops in Cairo on the Observatory parade ground at AbbasBieh, and in the evening a fête will be held at the Esbekieh Gardens in honour of the anniversary.
At Alexandria the anniversary is marked by an abondant display of flags of all nations, the Government departments making a special show.

H E the Governor of Alexandria held an , official reception at the Gonvemorat from 9 1 a.m. to noon, which was attended by the Gov- j ernmeut oivil aod military officials, the Con- ! sular Corps, and a latge number ot Dlema, j notables, and clergy of the oity. The pu- pits of the Orwa El-Woska schools, with their bands, numbering fifteen hundred, pa- I raded béfore the Governor, and then returned I to Mohamed Aly square, where they played tbe Khédivial Anthem in front of the statue of Mohamed Aly.
In the evening a banquet will be given by the Governor at the New Khédivial Hotel to the Government administrative officials and a Dumber ot notables of Alexandria.

div.head: RELIGIOUS TEACHING SCHOOLS.
div.p: Tbe native Press is at present much occn pied by the disoussion of the question of religions teaching iu the schools. "Al Watan," after pointing oat that Christians of every denomination, Jews, and Moslems frequent the Government sohools, aeks whether the Government is prepared to find and pay five religions instructors (one Moslem, one Hebrew, one Protestant, one Catholio, and one Orthodox) in every Bchool.Our contemporary continues: — "Tbe sohools will becomemo^qnes and churches. One pupil will be taaght the Christian dogmas, another the Moslem faith, while a third will learn that Christian and Moslem are benighted and astray from true religion ! The evil results of thiB innovation and all the disunion and trouble to wbioh it wonld give rise can easily be imagined."

div.head: JOURNALISTIC AMENITIES
div.p: "Al-Moayad" (k propos of a recent arriefc in "L'Egypte") says : This journal is acting in a very curious manner à propos of aiUbpen letter recently addressed to Idris Bey Ragheb and dealing with the names of Moslems, and in patticular that of the Prophet. Its treatment of this subject o»n only be described as vile, insolent, and degrading. . . . Thus 'L'Egypte' answers the paper which inserted the letter, its author, and the 'Journal du Caire' which translated it . . .

"This condoot constitutes a grave infraction of ordinary politeness and education, yet it seems much in fnvonrwith a journal that makes a point of insulting religions and their founders and heads. In onr opinion this cannot be condooive to the interests of Idris Bey R&gbeb, who finances the journal and declares himself responsible for all that it oodtains.

"Though be does not deserve the low and vile terms used by L'Egypte' towards its confrères, we should like him to realise that the j inrnalistic manners of 'L'Bgypte' ace likely to be paid in the same coin."

M. Colrat, the new editor of L'Egypte.' has certainly displayed an immense laok of good taste in dealing with religious matters since his assumption cf the editorship ef onr Cairo contemporary. A phra-e, "the oDnatnral creed of Christ," eccors to ns as an example of bis prowess in this direction. Free thonght seems to os to oe a poor exoose for bad manners

div.head: DUEL IN CAIRO
ENCOUNTER ON PYRAMIDS ROAD.
div.p: This morning, an interesting enoounter took place on the Pyramids-road, Cairo, between Mr. Henry de Vries, the well-known looal financier, and Aly Bey Kamel. The combatants exchanged two shots, with no resalt to either one or the other, and each then went on his own way.

div.head: THE NEW QUAY ESTATE.
div.p: The applications of the Khédivial Club, the Anglo-Egyptian Hotel Company, and of the lady who is the proprietress of an institution called the "Crystal Palaoe" for leases of land on the Dew quay estate, have been adjourned on the proposition of Mr. Esooffier until the next meeting of the Alexandria Mnnioipal Commission. The qaestion of whether the Municipality should or should not entertain applications for leases will then be thoroughly threshed out.

We onrselvea from the first have strongly advocated the leasing of all the bçst sites of this unique estate. Bat the oastoms of the ooantry are not yet edooated up to this soheme of property tenure. To the ordinary Englishman the idea of leasehold property is so simple that he ia at a loss to grasp the scarecrow which snoh a simple form of tenure appears to the native mind Yet, strange to state, the Dative regards the oomplioate tenure of hikr as one of the necessities of real property tenure, while to onr mind it is a most inoonvenient form of copyhold.

A very sensible proposition was made at the last meeting of the Mnnioipal Commission, that at the forthcoming auctions anyone to whom a lot wis sold should bave the right of declaring that, instead of 'paying the purchase pricer he would to take it on loDg lease st an interest of five per oent. on the purchase prioe.

div.head: RECORDED AT HELOUAN
div.p: The seismograph at Helonan Observatory reoorded on Friday last what wsb probably a very severe earthquake shook. The first tremors reaohed the Observatory at 8.30 a.m., Egyptian time, and the earthqaake probably ooonrred aotnally about fifteen minutes earlier. An inspection of tbe seismogram shows that the focos of the earthquake was about 8,000 kilometres away, and was probably to the east or west of the Observatory. If this was so, it took plaoe either in Mid-Atlantio oi in Central or Southern Asia. The seismograph was as violently disturbed as by the Valparaiso earthquake.

Les grosses valeurs sont moins en vogne.
L'Agrioole est cependant ferme k 9 21/32, ainsi qne la National Bank à 28 1/2, en hausse respective de 1/32 et 1/16.
En revaDohe, la Delta Light est nn pen pins faible k 11 13/16.
Les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie s'inscrivent k 201 202 et les Dividendes haussent de 350 à 351 1/2.
La Daira monte de 17 9/16 k 17 6/8, la Sait and Soda de 24 à 24 3, l'Obligation aDoienne Crédit Foncier de 339 1/2 à 340, la Banque d'Athènes de 137 1/2 k 138, et la Land Bank de 8 13/16 k 8 29/32.
Les Markets fléchissent an contraire de 31/3 k 31, l'Anglo American Nile de 5 3/4 k 5 11/16, les Nnngovioh Hotels de 23 À 22 15/16, et l'Urbaine de 7 11/16 k 7 5/8.
Le reste de la oote demeure sans changement.
Il y a en des affaires nn pen snr tontes les valears, mais particulièrement sur les Estates, le Comptoir, la Building, le Crédit Franoo- EgyptieD et l'Uuited.

L'Assemblée générale extraordinaire des Upper Egypt Hotels s'est teone samedi dernier 5 oonrant. A l'unanimité des membres présents et représentés elle a approuvé les résolutions provisoires prises le 22 décembre dernier. Les résolutions modifient comme soit les Statuts : 1.—A l'art. 36 ''l'Année sooiale commence le 1er avril et finit le 31 mars." 2.—An deuxième alinéa de l'art 29 : "Les assemblées généralos ordinaires ont lien chaque année dans le coarant des mois d'Avril on Mai, anx jours et lienx fixés par le Conseil d'Admiuiatration." 3.— A l'alinéa premier de l'art.5.— "La Société a nn oapital aotnel de 220.000 livres égyptiennes représenté par 55,000 aotions de LB. 4 chacune. Le Conseil d'administration est pourtant autorisé k augmenter le oapital, aux éprqnes et aux conditions qn'il déterminera, joFqn'k concurrence de la nomme de L.E 320 000 par la création de 25.000 aotions de

div.head: AN INTERESTING OUTING.
div.p: The direotion of the Wardan Estates Company yesterday entertained a large party of their shareholders, numbering about sevonty ladies aod gentlemen, at their estates at Wardan and Katatbah. A special train was provided, which left Cairo at 9.60 a.m. and proceeded to Uie northern end of the estate at Katatbah. Hired donkeys and a steam launch were provided, by which means the party were enabled to make a tonr of the greater part of these interesting properties, •and to witness the varions stages ot reclamation and onltivation in fall progress. The reclamation may be described as taking place in several stages. First, the planting oi a belt of trees to prevent sand drifts ; second, the levelling of the land ; third, the flooding of the land with red water to soon re the Nile mad deposit ; fourth, the sinking of*Abyssinian wells, for ultimate irrigation ; and lastly, the onltivation of varions crops.

As regards the trees and tree planting, nnrseries for raising these have been ereoted covering about five feddans, capable of producing from seed 800,000 trees per annum. A belt of trees fifty metres wide is being planted thronghont the length of the estate extending to 35 kilometres, and of this length some two thirds have been planted, while over the whole property an atea of 600 feddans has been planted. The levelling was originally commenced with cattle, but this was fonnd to be both too slow »Dd too costly, so six pairs of strong traotion engines are now at work with a M&olaren patent levelling sooop attached, capable of shovelling and lifting eight tons of sand at one time from a higher level and carrying it on to the lower ground, thuB rendering it all of one level. By this means it has been possible to level a very mnoh Urger area than oonld have been done by oatUe. Up to the present some 8.0r0 feddans haVe been levelled and are ready for onltivation as soon as the water supply by means of wells has been provided.

As regards the floodiog of the land, a main flood caoal has been oonstrnoted by the oompany which takes off from the Rayah Behera at about Kilo. 10 from the Barrage and runs thronghont the length of the estate,a distance of about 40 kilometres. The estate is divided into fonr basins, eaoh of which are flooded annually at high Nile. By this means a good layer of mod is deposited on the land. Irrigation of the reclaimed land is provided by means of Abyssinian wells, snnk in varions parts oi the property, of which there are at present completed or in coarse of construction some twenty seven, one oapable of supplying a 6-inoh centrifugal pomp, three 8-inoh, seventeen 10-inoh, and fonr 14 inoh pumps. The total well boring amounts to 13,600 metres, the wells having an average depth of 35 metres.

After haviog made extended visits and ( inspected the varions works in operation, the whole party repaired to the manager's honse, ' whore a most sumptuous repast had been provided under the personal superintendence of Mr. Wild, of the Savoy Hotel

At the close of lnnoheon Sir Hugh Smiley proposed the health of the directors, and in a few words congratulated the shareholders on the remarkable progress which bad been made with the work on the estates.' The chairman, Mr. Willi&mBon, appropriately replied and thanked the shareholders for the response they had given to the directors' invitation, as also Sir Hu ah Smiley for his enoonraging remarka.Mr. MoGillivray proposed the health of the manager, Mr. Whigham, and staff, pointing oat how tnnoh the shareholders were indebted to their ability in the management of their property. Mr. Whigham returned thanks, and after the health of the ladies had been most cordially received at the proposal of Mr. MoGillivray, the oompany dispersed, and Bfter strolling about the estate finally returned to Cairo by speoial train, arriving soon after Bix o'olook.

AmoDg those present we noticed : Sir Hngh and Lady Smiley, Mr. and Mrs. Williamson, Mr. McGillivray, Col. and Mrs. Gordon, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Lang Andersoo, Capt. and Mrs. Stookwell, Mr. and Mrs. Stoat, Mr. and Mrs. Hnseson, Mrs. Allan Joseph, Mrs. W. 0. Joseph, Capt. Adams, Mr. Raid, Mr. Rees, Mr. and Mrs. Rom. Mr. Barnard, Mr. F. H. Russell, Dr. and Mrs. Warnock, eto.

div.head: TALODI CAMPAIGN.

list.item: H. the Khedive has been mod graciously pleased to oommand that the Sadan Medal struck to oommemorate the military operations in connection with the reconquest of the DoDgola Province be conferred upon those (not already in possession of it) who took part in the operations at Talodi in Southern Kordofan in May and Jane 1906.

1. The medal will be granted to all troops (Regular and Irregular), who formed part of the garrison at Talodi between the 25th May ami the 12th Jane, both dates inclusive, or who belonged to the column nnder the com? mand of El Miralai O'Connel Bey, and who took part in the fightiDg at Taiara on the 15th and 17th Jane, 1906.

div.p: 2. A Clasp insoribed "Talodi" will be granted to all regolar troops who are entitled to tHe medal as above.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Saad Pasha Zaghlonl returned to Cairo yesterday morning from Upper Egypt in order to attend the Khédivial reception held to-day at Abdeen. The Minister of Bdr.oation goes this evening to 8ohag, wbenoe he will prooeed to the opper mondiriehs as far as Assouan, in order to oompiete his tonr of inspection.
H.H. the Khedive has oonferred the title of Mnlazim Awal on Ali Bffendi Fehmy Sarwat.
Sir William Holland, M.P., and Lady Holland left London last week for Bgypt.

Miss Balfonr, sister of the Hon. A. J. Balfour, is on her way oot to Egypt. Mr. Balfonr is down with influenza,and had to spend Christmas in London instead ot Wbittingh*rnp, where he had a large party tor the G . jrd ball, and Miss Balfonr is also suffering from a troublesome cold which she oannot get rid of.

Among the many residents of New York City who are spending some time in Egypt are General and Mrs. Stewart Woodford and Colonel and Mrs. Willis 3.' Paine. General Woodford is a leading member of the Bar of the Metropolis, and is highly gifted as an extemporaneous speaker, being mnoh in demand as a post prandial orator. He is at present up the Nile and will return to Cairo at the end of the month. Colonel Paine is a well-known financier and was appointed Rsoeiver of the largest savings bank that has ever failed. He afterwards became Bank Commissioner of the State of New York and all the financial institutions of that Commonwealth except the National Bank are under his charge. He h is just resigned the presidency of the consolidated National Bank to take a trip round the world. He is staying at the Ghezireh Palaoe Hotel.
The Grand Cordon of the Osmanieb, with the star and badge in brilliants, has been oonferred upon Masnrnr Pacha, the Turkish Ambassador in Jxmdon.

Among the naval officers whose promotions are gazetted in the list of New Year Honon rs are several who have rendered dntingnished servioe iu Egypt and theSadaD. Vice-Admiral A. B. Jennings, who attains fall flag rank, has seen forty-seven years' naval servioe. He gained his oaptainoy after the bombardment of Alexandria, when he was commander of the battleship Inflexible, of wfiioh the present Admiral of the Fleet, Sir John Fisher, was osptain. He subsequently aoted on the Ordnance Committee.

Rear-Admiral the Hon. SirHedworth Lambton, K.C.V.O., C.B., who becomes Vioe-Admiral, also serve! at Alexandria, while another officer who receives promotion, Rear- Admiral C. J. Noroook, foHght with distinction at Alexandria and Tel el-Kebir, and commanded the Heola in the operations in the Eastern Sudan.
Commander Cowan, who become J Captain, at the age of thirty six, won the 8irdar'a high prai?e when in oommand of the gnnboat flotilla on the Nile.
The salary of Cajptain Flower, the popular director of the Zoological Gardens, Cairo, has been raised to L E 800 per annum.
Dr. Graham has arrived at Alexandria from Cairo.
We regret to announce the death, which took plaoe at Ibrahimieh yesterday, of Mme.
We are pleased to announce that Mrs. John Wells has given birch to a daughter, and that mother and ohild are doing welL

div.head:
BRITISH FLEET
NEW COMPOSITION OF SQUADRONS

div.p: The "Daily Mail" gives the official details of the new composition of the fleets, praotioally confirming those of 15th of Ootober last 33 battleships in active commission are to be reduced to 26. 16 armoured cruisers arjs to be reduoed to 12. The Channel Fleet will be weaker than the German North Sea Fleet. (R.)

In order to better compete with the German lines, both for British aud Continental traffic, the White Star Company will transfer its midweek New York service from Liverpool to Southampton, iu June, and will oall at Cher bourg.
It is reported that the Canard and Orient Companies are contemplating a similar move.
(Reuter)

div.head:
KAISER AND UNITED STATES
TO STUDY PBOPLE AND COUNTRY.

div.p: The Emperor has sent an official, at bis own expense, to investigate into the commercial and financial oouditioDS in the United States. He is also sending six army officers to study the people and theoonntry. (Reuter)

div.head:
TRANSVAAL ELECTIONS.
BOERS AND CHINESE LABOUR.

div.p: The elections in the Transvaal are fixed to take place at the end of Fobruary, but the campaign has already begun. The Boer leaders have distinctly pronounced against interference on the Chinese labour question until an efficient substitute has been found. (Reuter)

div.head:
TRADE OF U K.
LARGE INCREASES>

div.p: The imports for the month of December show an inorease of £1,500,000, and the exports of £2,750,000 in comparison with the previous year. The total increases for the year amount to £43,000,000 and £45,750,000 respectively.
(Reuter)
Perceval De Bathe is dead.
(Reuter)
The Duke of the Abruuti has given a leoture on the exploration of the Ruwenzjri amidst the greatest applause. (Hams)
Altogether 15 men have been killed owing to the Rhiue Railway collapse. (Veuter)

div.head: A MEMORABLE RECORD
div.p: The "Sudan Times'' gives an interests g sommary of events in the Sudan daring the year 1906. Our contemporary says : — The year 1906 doses with a memorable record for the Sudan. It saw the completion cf the Red Sea Railway, which promises to oanae material change?, to the better, in the trade of the country as it brings ths Sudan mach nearer to the sea and consrqtiently to the other parts of the world. No Booner was this railway pot to use than the Dongola railway was opened to traffic, thus saving that province from the isolation it had been suffering from eversince the Kereima line was given up.

Preliminary wurk-i were also begun in connection with the projected railways to Kassala in the East and to Objid iu the We*t. Other minor reforms in communications were effected to which only a passing reference can be made These include an attempt to build a motor road between Khartoum and Kassala, roads for wheeled traffii in Bahr el-Ghiz»!, the sink ing of wells in various parts of the country, the improvement in some ferries, notably the Khartoum Omdurman ferry, the extensiori of the tramwiy iu Khartoum and Omdarman,
The year ha* been a prosperous one for trade. The prices of ivory rose iu the Loqdon market [ to almost unprecedented figures which meant m rj money for oar merchants here. The gam

which i--, at best, a very preoarious means of maintaining the population of a oonntry. T! e land settlement is a lengthy operation which se*s in motion all the machinery of the Government. This requires timerand patience. So far as we oan see from our detached position it will be years before the land problem is solved to allow of c iltivatiou of oottou or wheat on a large scale.
The Government has been enabled to promulgate during the year some valnable ordi*
Other ageucies are at work to promote the. cause of education in the country and they report unqualified success.

div.head: PROGRESS OF THE SUDAN MISSION.
div.p: which has recently been established at the request of Lori Cromer. It lies south of Khartoum, and redly firms a link between Egypt and Uganda — a vast territory thick'y populated with pagan tribe», who for yeais were under the despotic rule of the Mahdi and other pretenders. The Mn-shn consists of threo clergyme", a doctor, an agriculturist and instructor in industrial w.irk-all specially qualified ( <r the purpose. They have started tw * stations, and have asked the permission of the Government to start a third. Dr. Cook, who has come up from Uganda, is giving them the benefit of his long experience in Centra' Afdca. "All the par y are ir excellent health, and are learning thu language. Dr. Lloyd had treited as many as 900 patients at his dispensary up to Augrst.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN CENTRAL AFRICA.
div.p: Sir Alfred 3harpe, K.C.M.G., C.B., Governor of British Central Africa, baa addrossed to Mr. Winston Churchill an interesting letter dealing with cotton gmwiDg in the Protectorate, which has bien forwarded to the British Cotton Growing Association. Sir Alfred Sharpe states

It cannot bo said that this Protec'orate has made anything like a decided aucoess of cotton planting—as yet, whether it will do so eventual y is still a d lubtfnl question. The posi tion summarized is as follows:

The export of ootton in the year 1904 5 (the financial year) was 127 tons In the following (financial) year 1905 6 it rose to 346 tons, namely, more than doubled itself. The proa peots for the current (financial) year are uot so good, the export for the first sir months being only à-mat two thirls of what it was during the corresponding period ol the previous year. This falliiguff is due to a bad season, the rains having stopped earlier >ban usual.

Up to the present planters have not found a really suitable o> tton for the olimate. E/ypiian varieties do wallon the lower levels (the Shire River) and American Upland does best in the highlands (ap to 3,000ft. ab >ve sea level).

The fhortage ir. rainfall this year is ex oeptiona! and unfortunate, comiDg as it has doue at such a optical period. One good resolt of i\ however, has been (bat plsi ters are turning their attention to irrigation — which, for Egyptian c itton, on the rich, low lying alluvial fix's of the Shire R-ver is practically esrcntial. Ws know hero now that cotton cannot be planted without capital, uf wh ch there is far too little iu the conntry.

In his table of the year's pr< fit* in the Lancashire ootton industry, Mr, Willmm Tatteri&'l, of Manchester, gives for 65 mills the snm of £123,277. The share oapital oon cerned i« £2 529,667, and loans £1,257.12'. The pr- fit works out at the late uf lGj per cent, per annnm on share capital, If on the loans in'erest at 4^ per cent, is added to the profi declared, the rate od all capital employ ed is IV J percent, per annnm. A large number of mill companies do not issne printed balance- sheets. The re«n!ts for 1906 are not much d.fieront from those of 1905.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
div.p: To thb Editor op thk Egtptian Gazette

Sir,—Yonr correspondent ' Aoglo-Bgyptian," whose letter appears in your issue of the 8rd | instant, has hit the nail on the head in hie I remarks on the Egyptian National party. At I present it has no "ol&irn to a corporate existence as a genuine political movement," nor has it "passed beyond the stage of mere verbiage." ; The founders of the movement, which has been fostered chiefly by being written up in the

reins of government Oataide the noisy band of windbags and gassy orators there are tew Egyptians who are not influenced by motives of vanity or pecuniary profit, bat who have the real interests of their oonntry at heart, and who are trying to improve the moral and ednoational tone of the nation at large, bat unfortunately the two olasses are too often confused in the publio mir d i and are classified altogether as "Nationalists."

are well known, can and doobtleei will still remain a true 'Nationalist" in the better sense uf the term, in so mnoh as his present position will all the more enable him to support the cause of higher education, in relation to which be was oonspionoos before his appointment to the Ministry.—I am, eta, "Fair Plat."
Cairo, January 7, 1907,

div.head: TRIBUNAL COMMERCIAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
div.p: La Daira de Kasr-el-Aly contre la maison Lacarriere de Paris.
A l'andience commerciale de samedi dernier, présidée par M. Took, a été plaidée l'instance entre la Daïra de Kasr el-Aly et la mainon Laoarrière de Paris et divers portenrs de titre0.

Il B'agissait du remboursement d'une somme de 1 449.000 frs. payée en trop par la Daira pour la fourniture de mobilier et une demande de dommages intérêts de L.K. 40/ 00 pour le préjudice causé au crédit de la Daira par |j protêt qn'a laissé loi faire la maipon Laoarrère pour nne somme de 500,000 francs qu elle ré clamait encore et en oouverture de laquelle elle possédait des trBitesacceptée». Nona n'a von» pas k rechercher ici par qnels moyens et k la favenr de quelles complaisances cet excédent de 1 million 449,00J francs avait été payé à la maison Lacarrière et les 500.000 francs de traites protes'ées avaient été endossées.

La Dmra de Kasr-ol Aly représente la fortune de deux princesses veuves d'Ismsil pacha, les princesses Djenaniar Hanem et Tchen Afeb Hanem; le gérant de la Dsira, k l'épique do litige, était le prince Ibrahim Hilmy.
A l'andience, Me. Carton de Wiar», qui s'est présenté poor la Daïra, a exposé lo » raalti pies complications de ce procès.
Me. Chalom, poor la maison Lacarrière, a plaidé la nullité de l'assignation, invoqnaut qne la sigeifioation en avait é'é faite à M. Vernier, représentant au Caire de la maison Lacarrière.
Me. Oarloa de Wiart a soutenu que M, Ver nier représentait le domicile é'u stipulé dans le contrat de vente avec attribution f irmelle de la jnridiction.
Le tribunal jugeant l'incident au fond à ordonné de plaider.
Me. Chalom poor eou client a déclaré faire défaut.
Le jugement a é'é renvoyé k huitaine.

A la même audience, le tribunal avait è statuer bot la demande des porteurs des traites endossées par Laoarrière: l'Anglo Egyptian Bank,leCrédit Algérien, MM. Modiancfet Klein worst, représentés par Mcr F*tca et Bonboulis. Me. Carton de Wiart a plaidé qne la Daira de Kasr-el-Aly étant composée de deux femmes, j les traites Bonsorites ponr elle par nn manda j taire ne peuvent entraîner qu'une action civile et qne par conséquent le Tribunal de com meroe est incompétent. |

Subsidiairement si même le Tribunal se dé , clarait compétent la demande u'est pas reoev.v ! ble, parce que les endossements sont irré^n- liers, qn'ello a dû appeler en cause Laoarrière et qu elle ne doit pas payer des traites puis I qo'elle n'est pas débitrice de son foirnis»enr
Me. Chalom défend les mêmes raisons d'ex , ception et fait défaut au fonu.
Mes Fatioa et Bonbonlis s'efforcent de ccn- tester les argnments développés par Me Carton de Wiart.
Le président renvoie l'affaire à huitaine pour jugement

div.head: CHAMBRE CORRECTIONNELLE
div.p: Appel d'un Jugement de Contravention

Il a été qaeation ces jours derniers d'un scandale provoqué par la police indigène et qui a en son dénouement devant la chambre correction nelle siégeant en appal sur an jugement du Tribnnal des Conta vendons.

Cette ohambre avait condamné, sur procès ! verbal dressé par l'ofli:ier de polioe de Béni-, Sonef, nu négociant de cette localité, honora blemeot connu, M. Thomas Mikhaiiidis, à s-rpt jours de prison et k la fermeture de sa maison de commerce poor avoir déteuo du hachiche dans ses magasins.

Le oondamué a fait appel de ce jugement et la Chambre correctionelle présidée par M Vasque/ a cru devoir, aprèt de nouveaux el minitienx débats, casser le jugemeut du Tri- buoaldes contraventions et renvoyer M Mikhn lidis des fi is de la plainte portés contre lui.

Il a été démontré que le procès verbal do esnstatation de hachiche dans les magasin» de M Mikhai'idis était l'œuvre d'une vengoauo* contre ce négonjant. et que le produit pn hlbé avait été apporte etdéoosé dans les locaux du cirnmeruuit par les of fi iers de pJioa eux mêmes.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
